added_lines: def test_state_init(self): tmpl = rsrc_defn.ResourceDefinition('test_resource', 'Foo') res = generic_rsrc.GenericResource('test_resource', tmpl, self.stack) res.state_init() self.assertIsNotNone(res.id) self.assertEqual((res.INIT, res.COMPLETE), res.state) self.assertEqual('Resource initialized', res.status_reason) # Prove the initialized resource has been persisted to the DB db_res = resource_objects.Resource.get_obj(res.context, res.id) self.assertEqual(res.INIT, db_res.action) self.assertEqual(res.COMPLETE, db_res.status) self.assertEqual('Resource initialized', db_res.status_reason) # And that an event has been generated events = db_api.event_get_all_by_stack(res.context, self.stack.id) self.assertEqual(1, len(events)) self.assertEqual(res.INIT, events[0].resource_action) self.assertEqual(res.COMPLETE, events[0].resource_status) res._store_or_update(res.INIT, res.COMPLETE, 'test_store') self.assertEqual(res.INIT, res.action) self.assertEqual(res.COMPLETE, res.status) self.assertEqual('test_store', res.status_reason) db_res = resource_objects.Resource.get_obj(res.context, res.id) self.assertEqual(res.INIT, db_res.action) self.assertEqual(res.COMPLETE, db_res.status) self.assertEqual('test_store', db_res.status_reason) res._store_or_update(res.CREATE, res.IN_PROGRESS, 'test_create') self.assertEqual('test_create', res.status_reason) db_res.refresh() self.assertEqual('test_create', db_res.status_reason)
deleted_lines: res._store_or_update(res.CREATE, res.IN_PROGRESS, 'test_store') self.assertEqual('test_store', res.status_reason) db_res = resource_objects.Resource.get_obj(res.context, res.id) self.assertEqual('test_store', db_res.status_reason)

commit_message:
Resource persist state_reset to DB

When doing state_reset, we currently only do an in-memory reset of
state when calling state_reset, but persisting to the DB makes it
useful for general resource initialization, not just the Stack
restart_resource implementation (which we really want to die after
we manage to remove HARestarter).

Change-Id: I2da2ef4c6be790dfe20b3209d606ee1739b080d8
Partial-Bug: #1319813
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/24/165624/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_state_reset(self): tmpl = rsrc_defn.ResourceDefinition('test_resource', 'Foo') res = generic_rsrc.GenericResource('test_resource', tmpl, self.stack) res.state_reset() self.assertIsNotNone(res.id) self.assertEqual((res.INIT, res.COMPLETE), res.state) self.assertEqual('Resource initialized', res.status_reason) # Prove the initialized resource has been persisted to the DB db_res = resource_objects.Resource.get_obj(res.context, res.id) self.assertEqual(res.INIT, db_res.action) self.assertEqual(res.COMPLETE, db_res.status) self.assertEqual('Resource initialized', db_res.status_reason) # And that an event has been generated events = db_api.event_get_all_by_stack(res.context, self.stack.id) self.assertEqual(1, len(events)) self.assertEqual(res.INIT, events[0].resource_action) self.assertEqual(res.COMPLETE, events[0].resource_status)

commit_message:
Improve creation of expected assignments in tests

Creation of expected role assignment entities and
links are in separate methods. The advantage is
to only create the link on methods that do not
need the entity. Test references are fixed.

In addition, expected assignment link is get from
the expected entity, instead of from a separate
attribute on assert methods at test_v3.

Partial-Bug: 1406640

Change-Id: I7c81dcf2627f2bfb712591cb33abd6fd03a3a52a

added_lines: import re # role assignment validation if expected_length: # Collections should have relational links def assertValidRoleAssignment(self, entity, ref=None): links = ref.pop('links') self.assertIsNotNone(re.match('.+%s' % links['assignment'], l['assignment'])) finally: ref['links'] = links def assertRoleAssignmentInListResponse(self, resp, ref, expected=1): self.assertValidRoleAssignment(entity, ref=ref) def assertRoleAssignmentNotInListResponse(self, resp, ref): self.assertRoleAssignmentInListResponse(resp, ref=ref, expected=0)
deleted_lines: if expected_length is not None: # collections should have relational links def assertValidRoleAssignment(self, entity, ref=None, url=None): links = ref.pop('links', None) finally: if links: ref['links'] = links if url: self.assertIn(url, l['assignment']) def assertRoleAssignmentInListResponse( self, resp, ref, link_url=None, expected=1): self.assertValidRoleAssignment( entity, ref=ref, url=link_url) def assertRoleAssignmentNotInListResponse( self, resp, ref, link_url=None): self.assertRoleAssignmentInListResponse( resp, ref=ref, link_url=link_url, expected=0)

commit_message:
Update puppet post config to enable stepped deployments

The upcoming heat hook/breakpoint features will enable stepped deployments
via setting stop points via the resource_registry.

For this to work, we need hard dependencies between each step of the
puppet deployments, because the current "soft" dependencies caused by the
name property only influences the hook script application ordering, not
the graph traversed by heat during deployment.

Since removing the name: puppet_n completely removes some useful self-
documenting context, move this to a resource naming convention, which
should also be useful for heat hooks/breakpoints, as they are expected
to support globbed specification of each step.

Related heat patch (not yet landed, but this is not dependent on it):

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/146123/

Change-Id: I05b02a46d4e80c08a308d033c33d4901c8f6c94e

commit_message:
Add data sync cli wrappers

Adds the handlers for the CLI requried by the data sync
operation defined in the specification kilo/data_sync.

The functionaly for each CLI will be implemented in
later commits.

Change-Id: I9d7480eb87f815d0d2aa7d2fc0d5e135ebe7d594
Signed-off-by: Joe Mills <joe@midokura.com>
Partially-Implements: kilo/data_sync
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/networking-midonet refs/changes/46/164946/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def data_show(config, cmd): pass def data_readonly(config, cmd): pass def data_readwrite(config, cmd): pass def data_version_list(config, cmd): pass def data_version_sync(config, cmd): pass def data_version_activate(config, cmd): pass parser = subparsers.add_parser('data-show') parser.set_defaults(func=data_show) parser = subparsers.add_parser('data-readonly') parser.set_defaults(func=data_readonly) parser = subparsers.add_parser('data-readwrite') parser.set_defaults(func=data_readwrite) parser = subparsers.add_parser('data-version-list') parser.set_defaults(func=data_version_list) parser = subparsers.add_parser('data-version-sync') parser.set_defaults(func=data_version_sync) parser = subparsers.add_parser('data-version-activate') parser.set_defaults(func=data_version_activate)

subject: Replace keepalived notifier bash script with Python ip monitor
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-10-01 15:17:01.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/c0f12d89ce41df86b72b5bf1c32be0d76762b1c9', 'message': "Replace keepalived notifier bash script with Python

Previously L3 HA generated a bash script and copied it to a per-router
configuration directory that was visible to that router's keepalived
instance.

This patch changes the in-line generated Bash script to a Python script
that can be maintained in the repository. This patch maintains the
Bash script's functionality, while the next patch in the series
will expand said functionality.

Related-Bug: #1365453
Change-Id: I2022bced330d5f108fbedd40548a901225d7ea1c

"}, {'number': 9, 'created': '2014-12-07 15:27:25.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/fa11652bc665e1ed8fbdefb7992ea08e2bea9c5e', 'message': "Replace keepalived notifier bash script with Python

Previously L3 HA generated a bash script and copied it to a per-router
configuration directory that was visible to that router's keepalived
instance. This patch changes the in-line generated Bash script to a
Python script that can be maintained in the repository.

neutron-keepalived-state-change is invoked by keepalived whenever
a state change occurs. That script notifies the L3 agent that
the event occured via a unix domain socket. At first, the agent
will simply log that the event occured. In the future it will
report state changes to the server via RPC.

Related-Bug: #1365453
Closes-Bug: #1367705
Partially-Implements: blueprint report-ha-router-master
Change-Id: I2022bced330d5f108fbedd40548a901225d7ea1c
"}, {'number': 10, 'created': '2014-12-07 17:54:23.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/d62f57027b5db88415ccd80371f051a05f6f358a', 'message': "Replace keepalived notifier bash script with Python

"}, {'number': 12, 'created': '2015-01-27 21:04:27.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/ad93d6635801d3086a596cf06b50ee1f942fd306', 'message': "Replace keepalived notifier bash script with Python ip monitor

Previously L3 HA generated a bash script and copied it to a per-router
configuration directory that was visible to that router's keepalived
instance. This patch changes the in-line generated Bash script to a
Python script that can be maintained in the repository.

The bash script was used as a keepalived notifier script, that was invoked
by keepalived whenever a state transition occured. These notifier scripts
may be invoked by keepalived out of order in case it transitions quickly
twice. For example, if the master failed and two slaves fight for the new
master role. One will transition to master, and the other will often
transition to master and then immidiately back to standby. In this case,
the transition scripts were often fired out of order, resulting in the
wrong state being reported.

The proposed approach is to get rid of the keepalived notifier scripts
entirely. Instead, monitor IP changes on the HA device. If the omnipresent
IP addresses was configured on the HA device, it means that we're looking
at a master instance. If it was deleted, the router transition to standby
or fault.

In order to keep the L3 agent CPU usage down, it will spawn a process
per HA router. That process will start 'ip monitor address'. Whenever
it gets an IP address change event, it will notify the L3 agent via
a unix domain socket.

Change-Id: I2022bced330d5f108fbedd40548a901225d7ea1c
Closes-Bug: #1402010
"}, {'number': 13, 'created': '2015-01-28 00:25:55.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/ba27fc6a31b4a03973a69ce605d259add4d3135a', 'message': "Replace keepalived notifier bash script with Python ip monitor

Previously L3 HA generated a bash script and copied it to a per-router
configuration directory that was visible to that router's keepalived
instance. This patch changes the in-line generated Bash script to a
Python script that can be maintained in the repository.

The bash script was used as a keepalived notifier script, that was invoked
by keepalived whenever a state transition occured. These notifier scripts
may be invoked by keepalived out of order in case it transitions quickly
twice. For example, if the master failed and two slaves fight for the new
master role. One will transition to master, and the other will often
transition to master and then immidiately back to standby. In this case,
the transition scripts were often fired out of order, resulting in the
wrong state being reported.

The proposed approach is to get rid of the keepalived notifier scripts
entirely. Instead, monitor IP changes on the HA device. If the omnipresent
IP addresses was configured on the HA device, it means that we're looking
at a master instance. If it was deleted, the router transition to standby
or fault.

In order to keep the L3 agent CPU usage down, it will spawn a process
per HA router. That process will start 'ip monitor address'. Whenever
it gets an IP address change event, it will notify the L3 agent via
a unix domain socket.

Change-Id: I2022bced330d5f108fbedd40548a901225d7ea1c
Closes-Bug: #1402010

commit_message:
Replace keepalived notifier bash script with Python ip monitor

Previously L3 HA generated a bash script and copied it to a per-router
configuration directory that was visible to that router's keepalived
instance. This patch changes the in-line generated Bash script to a
Python script that can be maintained in the repository.
The bash script was used as a keepalived notifier script, that was invoked
by keepalived whenever a state transition occured. These notifier scripts
may be invoked by keepalived out of order in case it transitions quickly
twice. For example, if the master failed and two slaves fight for the new
master role. One will transition to master, and the other will often
transition to master and then immidiately back to standby. In this case,
the transition scripts were often fired out of order, resulting in the
wrong state being reported.

The proposed approach is to get rid of the keepalived notifier scripts
entirely. Instead, monitor IP changes on the HA device. If the omnipresent
IP address was configured on the HA device, it means that we're looking
at a master instance. If it was deleted, the router transition to standby
or fault.

In order to keep the L3 agent CPU usage down, it will spawn a process
per HA router. That process will start the ip address monitor.
Whenever it gets an IP address change event, it will notify the L3 agent
via a unix domain socket.

Partially-Implements: blueprint report-ha-router-master
Change-Id: I2022bced330d5f108fbedd40548a901225d7ea1c
Closes-Bug: #1402010
Closes-Bug: #1367705

commit_message:
Remove pci_device.update_device helper function

This function is an exact copy of the PciDevice.update_device object
method, and we use it only in the PciDevTracker that has been
objectified a long time ago (likely by mistake).

This patch removes this useless duplication of code.

Change-Id: I3a2e49a79feef71bd606ae50fb02cede25a43d62
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/12/165512/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: def update_device(devobj, dev_dict): """Sync the content from device dictionary to device object. The resource tracker updates the available devices periodically. To avoid meaningless syncs with the database, we update the device object only if a value changed. """ # Note(yjiang5): status/instance_uuid should only be updated by # functions like claim/allocate etc. The id is allocated by # database. The extra_info is created by the object. no_changes = ('status', 'instance_uuid', 'id', 'extra_info') map(lambda x: dev_dict.pop(x, None), [key for key in no_changes]) for k, v in dev_dict.items(): if k in devobj.fields.keys(): devobj[k] = v else: # Note (yjiang5) extra_info.update does not update # obj_what_changed, set it explicitely extra_info = devobj.extra_info extra_info.update({k: v}) devobj.extra_info = extra_info

commit_message:
Make unused iscsi_num_targets, iser_num_targets configs as deprecated

After introducing new iscsi target driver model via Change-Id:
I43190d1dac33748fe55fa00f260f32ab209be656, configuration
options of iscsi_num_targets and iser_num_targets are not
used in these new scsi targets.

This patch makes these unused configuration options as
deprecated and adds warning messages to notify future removal
of these configs to users.

Also this patch removes _ensure_iscsi_targets() which uses these
two config options from cxt scsi target because this method is
never called anywhere.

Closes-Bug: #1427904
DocImpact: Two unused config options are deprecated
Change-Id: Ic34910f4765f46e2708de7cb686e49418f486709

commit_message:
Verify all quotas before updating the db

Update quota multi-value in one request is not an atomicity operation,
so even if a quota is invalid (Ex: ram less than already used), some values
may change but the return code is 400.

This patch will first check all the quotas before hitting trying to update
the quotas.

First submitted as part of changeset:
I22171c1f1f8171c502f2a9d710cfac38f5b38d85

Co-Authored-By: Leandro I. Costantino <leandro.i.costantino@intel.com>
Closes-Bug: #1291199
Change-Id: I76aa20c0254666b59b93497a63c81981ada0a7b2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/68/163668/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: valid_quotas = {} valid_quotas[key] = value for key, value in valid_quotas.items():

commit_message:
Add deprecation warnings

The schema of the commands and some of the commands
themselves are going to be deprecated.

This patch adds a deprecation warning with the instructions
to the help message in order to make users aware of the changes.

Change-Id: I97100299d50290bcad8f2e6c6eb3861bdd1500c6
Blueprint: re-thinking-fuel-client
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-fuelclient refs/changes/55/162155/9 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Default configuration for Fuel Client is the following: SERVER_ADDRESS: "127.0.0.1" LISTEN_PORT: "8000" KEYSTONE_USER: "admin" KEYSTONE_PASS: "admin" These options can be changed by putting some or all of them into a yaml-formatted textfile and specifying its full path in the FUELCLIENT_CUSTOM_SETTINGS enviroment variable. fuel [optional args] <namespace> [action] [flags] DEPRECATION WARNING: In the following release the schema of commands will be changed to the following one fuel [general flags] <entity> <action> [action flags] where both [general flags] and [action flags] are derivatives from [optional args] and [flags]; <entity> is a derivative from <namespace>. Keep in mind, that ispecifying <action> will be mandatory. Some of the [optional args] are going to be context-specific in the following release of Fuel Client so specifying them before either <namespace> or [action] will not be possible. Example: Correct: fuel node list --env 1 Wrong: fuel --env 1 node list The table bellowof the commands which are going to be removed or changed significantly. +--------------------------------------------------------+ | Old command | New command | +------------------------+-------------------------------+ | fuel deploy-changes | fuel env deploy | +------------------------+-------------------------------+ | fuel node --set --env | fuel env add nodes | +------------------------+-------------------------------+ To check out the demo run fuel2 --help END OF THE DEPRECATION WARNING. """
deleted_lines: Configuration for client you can find in /etc/fuel/client/config.yaml. If you don't have this file please create it i.e.: "SERVER_ADDRESS": "127.0.0.1", "LISTEN_PORT": "8000", "KEYSTONE_USER": "admin", "KEYSTONE_PASS": "admin" fuel [optional args] <namespace> [action] [flags]"""

dashboards/project/data_processing/wizard/templates/data_processing.wizard/_job_type_select_help.html:3 msgid "" "Select which type of job that you want to run.
" " This choice will dictate which steps are required to successfully
" " execute your job.
" " " msgstr "" #: dashboards/project/data_processing/wizard/templates/data_processing.wizard/_plugin_select.html:13 #: dashboards/project/data_processing/wizard/templates/data_processing.wizard/plugin_select.html:3 #: dashboards/project/data_processing/wizard/templates/data_processing.wizard/plugin_select.html:6 msgid "Choose plugin and version" msgstr "" #: dashboards/project/data_processing/wizard/templates/data_processing.wizard/_plugin_select_help.html:3 msgid "" "Select which plugin and version that you
" " want to use to create your cluster." msgstr "" #: dashboards/project/data_processing/wizard/templates/data_processing.wizard/cluster_guide.html:7 msgid "Guided Cluster Creation" msgstr "" #: dashboards/project/data_processing/wizard/templates/data_processing.wizard/cluster_guide.html:16 msgid "" "The first step is to determine which type of
" " cluster you want to run. You may have several choices
" " available depending on the configuration of your system.
" " Click on "choose plugin" to bring up the list of data
" " processing plugins. There you will be able to choose the
" " data processing plugin along with the version number.
" " Choosing this up front will allow the rest of the cluster
" " creation steps to focus only on options that are pertinent
" " to your desired cluster type." msgstr "" #: dashboards/project/data_processing/wizard/templates/data_processing.wizard/cluster_guide.html:27 msgid "Choose plugin" msgstr "" #: dashboards/project/data_processing/wizard/templates/data_processing.wizard/cluster_guide.html:28 #: dashboards/project/data_processing/wizard/templates/data_processing.wizard/cluster_guide.html:64 #: dashboards/project/data_processing/wizard/templates/data_processing.wizard/cluster_guide.html:91 #: dashboards/project/data_processing/wizard/templates/data_processing.wizard/cluster_guide.html:123 msgid "Current choice:" msgstr "" #: dashboards/project/data_processing/wizard/templates/data_processing.wizard/cluster_guide.html:31 msgid "Plugin:" msgstr "" #: dashboards/project/data_processing/wizard/templates/data_processing.wizard/cluster_guide.html:33 msgid "Version:" msgstr "" #: dashboards/project/data_processing/wizard/templates/data_processing.wizard/cluster_guide.html:38 msgid "No plugin chosen" msgstr "" #: dashboards/project/data_processing/wizard/templates/data_processing.wizard/cluster_guide.html:47 msgid "" "Next, you need to define the different
" " types of machines in your cluster. This is done by
" " defining a Node Group Template for each type of
" " machine. A very common case is where you
" " need to have one or more machines running a "master"
" " set of processes while another set of machines need
" " to be running the "worker" processes. Here,
" " you will define the Node Group Template for your
" " "master" node(s).
" " " msgstr "" #: dashboards/project/data_processing/wizard/templates/data_processing.wizard/cluster_guide.html:62 msgid "Create a Master Node Group Template" msgstr "" #: dashboards/project/data_processing/wizard/templates/data_processing.wizard/cluster_guide.html:67 msgid "Master Node Group Template:" msgstr "" #: dashboards/project/data_processing/wizard/templates/data_processing.wizard/cluster_guide.html:72 msgid "No Master Node Group Template Created" msgstr "" #: dashboards/project/data_processing/wizard/templates/data_processing.wizard/cluster_guide.html:81 msgid "" "Repeat the Node Group Template
" " creation process, but this time you are creating
" " your "worker" Node Group Template." msgstr "" #: dashboards/project/data_processing/wizard/templates/data_processing.wizard/cluster_guide.html:89 msgid "Create a Worker Node Group Template" msgstr "" #: dashboards/project/data_processing/wizard/templates/data_processing.wizard/cluster_guide.html:94 #: dashboards/project/data_processing/wizard/templates/data_processing.wizard/cluster_guide.html:126 msgid "Worker Node Group Template:" msgstr "" #: dashboards/project/data_processing/wizard/templates/data_processing.wizard/cluster_guide.html:99 msgid "No Worker Node Group Template Created" msgstr "" #: dashboards/project/data_processing/wizard/templates/data_processing.wizard/cluster_guide.html:108 msgid "" "Now you need to set the layout of your
" " cluster. By
" " creating a Cluster Template, you will be choosing the
" " number of instances of each Node Group Template that
" " will appear in your cluster. Additionally,
" " you will have a chance to set any cluster-specific
" " configuration items in the additional tabs on the
" " create Cluster Template form." msgstr "" #: dashboards/project/data_processing/wizard/templates/data_processing.wizard/cluster_guide.html:121 msgid "Create a Cluster Template" msgstr "" #: dashboards/project/data_processing/wizard/templates/data_processing.wizard/cluster_guide.html:131 msgid "No Cluster Template Created" msgstr "" #: dashboards/project/data_processing/wizard/templates/data_processing.wizard/cluster_guide.html:140 msgid "" "You are now ready to
" " launch your cluster. When you click on the link
" " below, you will need to give your cluster a name,
" " choose the Cluster Template to use and choose which
" " image to use to build your instances. After you
" " click on "Create", your instances will begin to
" " spawn. Your cluster should be operational in a few
" " minutes." msgstr "" #: dashboards/project/data_processing/wizard/templates/data_processing.wizard/cluster_guide.html:153 msgid "Launch a Cluster" msgstr "" #: dashboards/project/data_processing/wizard/templates/data_processing.wizard/cluster_guide.html:161 msgid "Reset Cluster Guide" msgstr "" #: dashboards/project/data_processing/wizard/templates/data_processing.wizard/cluster_guide.html:163 msgid "Reset Cluster Creation Guide" msgstr "" #: dashboards/project/data_processing/wizard/templates/data_processing.wizard/jobex_guide.html:7 msgid "Guided Job Execution" msgstr "" #: dashboards/project/data_processing/wizard/templates/data_processing.wizard/jobex_guide.html:17 msgid "" "First, select which type of job that
" " you want to run. This choice will determine which
" " other steps are required
" " " msgstr "" #: dashboards/project/data_processing/wizard/templates/data_processing.wizard/jobex_guide.html:25 msgid "Select type" msgstr "" #: dashboards/project/data_processing/wizard/templates/data_processing.wizard/jobex_guide.html:28 msgid "Current type:" msgstr "" #: dashboards/project/data_processing/wizard/templates/data_processing.wizard/jobex_guide.html:35 msgid "No type chosen" msgstr "" #: dashboards/project/data_processing/wizard/templates/data_processing.wizard/jobex_guide.html:46 msgid "" "Data Sources are what your
" " job uses for input and output. Depending on the type
" " of job you will be running, you may need to define one
" " or more data sources. You can create multiple data
" " sources by repeating this step.
" " " msgstr "" #: dashboards/project/data_processing/wizard/templates/data_processing.wizard/jobex_guide.html:56 msgid "Create a data source" msgstr "" #: dashboards/project/data_processing/wizard/templates/data_processing.wizard/jobex_guide.html:65 msgid "" "Define your Job Template.
" " This is where you choose the type of job that you
" " want to run (Pig, Java Action, Spark, etc) and choose
" " or upload the files necessary to run it. The inputs
" " and outputs will be defined later.
" " " msgstr "" #: dashboards/project/data_processing/wizard/templates/data_processing.wizard/jobex_guide.html:75 msgid "Create a job template" msgstr "" #: dashboards/project/data_processing/wizard/templates/data_processing.wizard/jobex_guide.html:77 msgid "Job template:" msgstr "" #: dashboards/project/data_processing/wizard/templates/data_processing.wizard/jobex_guide.html:84 msgid "No job template created" msgstr "" #: dashboards/project/data_processing/wizard/templates/data_processing.wizard/jobex_guide.html:93 msgid "" "Launch your job. When
" " launching, you may need to choose your input and
" " output data sources. This is where you would also
" " add any special configuration values, parameters,
" " or arguments that you need to pass along
" " to your job.
" " " msgstr "" #: dashboards/project/data_processing/wizard/templates/data_processing.wizard/jobex_guide.html:103 msgid "Launch job" msgstr "" #: dashboards/project/data_processing/wizard/templates/data_processing.wizard/jobex_guide.html:112 #: dashboards/project/data_processing/wizard/templates/data_processing.wizard/jobex_guide.html:114 msgid "Reset Job Execution Guide" msgstr "" #: dashboards/project/data_processing/wizard/templates/data_processing.wizard/wizard.html:7 msgid "Data Processing Guides" msgstr "" #: dashboards/project/data_processing/wizard/templates/data_processing.wizard/wizard.html:16 msgid "" "
" " Each of the Data Processing frameworks require a cluster of machines
" " in order to do the work they are assigned. A cluster is
" " formed by creating a set of Node Group Templates, combining
" " those into a Cluster Template and then launching a Cluster.
" " You can do each of those steps manually, or you can follow
" " this guide to help take you through the steps of
" " Cluster creation.
" " " msgstr "" #: dashboards/project/data_processing/wizard/templates/data_processing.wizard/wizard.html:29 msgid "Cluster Guide" msgstr "" #: dashboards/project/data_processing/wizard/templates/data_processing.wizard/wizard.html:38 msgid "" "
" " In order to run a Data Processing job, you need to make
" " the files for your program available to the
" " Data Processing system, define where the input and output
" " need to go and create a Job Template that describes
" " how to run your job. Each of those steps can be done
" " manually or you can follow this guide to help take you
" " through the steps to run a job on an existing cluster.
" " " msgstr ""

commit_message:
load ram_allocation_ratio when asked

The previous code loaded the CONF.ram_allocation_ratio at eval time of
the class, which means that it's impossible to override via
configuration after the fact. It breaks This is no reason to make this a const
value so early on in the process. The aggregate ram filter below this
class loads from CONF every time, so this seems the right thing to do.

This also fixes the unit tests to be safe. Previously these were
modifying global values for oversubscribe ratios which would not be
reset in follow on tests.

This is effectively a revert of
I433cbbdbef4ac3c01a3e2b6ed5cf092a5cce6372

The optimization in the above patch meant that this value no longer
was overridable in tests in a standard way. It also meant that changes
to this value would not be applied during a service restart, although
all other variables would.

Change-Id: I49758b4b3fcb6219e7b8bc73adb7c9bcf31f0bea

commit_message:
let fake virt track resources

For building scheduling test cases we need the fake virt driver to
actually track the allocated resources to trigger scheduler out of
resource logic. This provides a simple allocator / deallocator model
for that.

Change-Id: Ifa006f70b9bbb0c0b2a5db066e1ba87aa1b50b34
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/76/165376/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: class Resources(object): vcpus = 0 memory_mb = 0 local_gb = 0 vcpus_used = 0 memory_mb_used = 0 local_gb_used = 0 def __init__(self, vcpus=8, memory_mb=8000, local_gb=500): self.vcpus = vcpus self.memory_mb = memory_mb self.local_gb = local_gb def claim(self, vcpus=0, mem=0, disk=0): self.vcpus_used += vcpus self.memory_mb_used += mem self.local_gb_used += disk def release(self, vcpus=0, mem=0, disk=0): self.vcpus_used -= vcpus self.memory_mb_used -= mem self.local_gb_used -= disk def dump(self): return { 'vcpus': self.vcpus, 'memory_mb': self.memory_mb, 'local_gb': self.local_gb, 'vcpus_used': self.vcpus_used, 'memory_mb_used': self.memory_mb_used, 'local_gb_used': self.local_gb_used } self.resources = Resources( vcpus=self.vcpus, memory_mb=self.memory_mb, local_gb=self.local_gb) self.host_status_base = { flavor = instance.flavor self.resources.claim( vcpus=flavor.vcpus, mem=flavor.memory_mb, disk=flavor.root_gb) flavor = instance.flavor self.resources.release( vcpus=flavor.vcpus, mem=flavor.memory_mb, disk=flavor.root_gb) host_status.update(self.resources.dump())
deleted_lines: self.host_status_base = { 'vcpus': self.vcpus, 'memory_mb': self.memory_mb, 'local_gb': self.local_gb, 'vcpus_used': 0, 'memory_mb_used': 0, 'local_gb_used': 100000000000,

commit_message:
tests: stop overwriting neutron BaseTestCase configuration files

It's ok to expect configuration files that are passed by neutron's
BaseTestCase, since they are located in the python package itself (under
site-packages).

Related-Bug: #1433146
Change-Id: If1f5ebd981cf06558d5102524211799676068889
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-vpnaas refs/changes/21/165421/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
tests: stop overwriting neutron BaseTestCase configuration files

It's ok to expect configuration files that are passed by neutron's
BaseTestCase, since they are located in the python package itself (under
site-packages).

Related-Bug: #1433146
Change-Id: If1f5ebd981cf06558d5102524211799676068889
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-lbaas refs/changes/17/165417/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: class BaseTestCase(n_base.BaseTestCase): pass pass pass
deleted_lines: import os import neutronfrom oslo_config import cfgdef override_nvalues(): neutron_path = os.path.abspath( os.path.join(os.path.dirname(neutron.__file__), os.pardir)) neutron_policy = os.path.join(neutron_path, 'etc/policy.json') cfg.CONF.set_override('policy_file', neutron_policy) class BaseTestCase(n_base.BaseTestCase): def setUp(self): override_nvalues() super(BaseTestCase, self).setUp() def setUp(self, plugin=None, service_plugins=None, ext_mgr=None): override_nvalues() # NOTE(blogan): this prevents the neutron serviceprovider code from # parsing real configs in /etc/neutron cfg.CONF.config_dir = '' super(NeutronDbPluginV2TestCase, self).setUp( plugin, service_plugins, ext_mgr) def setUp(self): override_nvalues() super(ExtensionTestCase, self).setUp() def setUp(self): override_nvalues() super(QuotaExtensionTestCase, self).setUp()

commit_message:
Updated TODO list

- added one item about api spec -- sorting by fields;
- removed multi-region/cloud item, which seems working now
- renamed priv management to access control.

Change-Id: Ie32bcfcc7a44b2ac897b60b2ea7b07da4fd58811
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/senlin refs/changes/10/165710/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - Provide support for access control [Yanyan Hu] - Revise the API for sorting, based on the following guideline: https://github.com/openstack/api-wg/blob/master/guidelines/pagination_filter_sort.rst
deleted_lines: - Add the support for the multi-region/multi-cloud in profile (Qi Zhang) Need to add one more column in Profile as identifier, if the cloud is openstack, this identifier will be the region name which will be used to get the right service via openstackSDK. If the cloud type is bluemix, this will be the bluemix API address. - Provide support for privilege management [Yanyan Hu]

commit_message:
Quick fix of dockerctl behaviour

'dockerctl shell <cotainer> <command>' hungs if it is executed
from system tests. Empty string that send to stdin helps to prevent
this hung.

Change-Id: Idffce896dada091fcadbd956718a97b111cb0966
Related-Bug: #1433836
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-qa refs/changes/68/165668/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: stdin=''): cmd = ('echo "{2}" | dockerctl shell {0} {1}' .format(container, command, stdin))
deleted_lines: stdin=None): cmd = 'dockerctl shell {0} {1}'.format(container, command) if stdin is not None: cmd = 'echo "{0}" | {1}'.format(stdin, cmd)

commit_message:
Migration of cli sections in End User Guide

DocBook to RST conversion of the following sections:

- Manage instances and hosts
- Change the size of your server
- Manage IP addresses
- Start and stop an instance
- Provide user data to instances

Change-Id: Id3a2c1aa9ad7d44fac87274b14e4a1f4ced9539b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/70/157270/14 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ========================== Stop and start an instance ========================== Use one of the following methods to stop and start an instance. Pause and unpause an instance ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ To pause an instance, run the following command: .. code:: $ nova pause INSTANCE_NAME This command stores the state of the VM in RAM. A paused instance continues to run in a frozen state. To unpause an instance, run the following command: ..code:: $ nova unpause INSTANCE_NAME Suspend and resume an instance ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ To initiate a hypervisor-level suspend operation, run the following command: .. code:: $ nova suspend INSTANCE_NAME To resume a suspended instance, run the following command: .. code:: $ nova resume INSTANCE_NAME Shelve and unshelve an instance ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ Shelving is useful if you have an instance that you are not using, but would like retain in your list of servers. For example, you can stop an instance at the end of a work week, and resume work again at the start of the next week. All associated data and resources are kept; however, anything still in memory is not retained. If a shelved instance is no longer needed, it can also be entirely removed. You can complete the following shelving tasks: - Shelve an instance - Shuts down the instance, and stores it together with associated data and resources (a snapshot is taken if not volume backed). Anything in memory is lost. Use the following command: .. code:: $ nova shelve SERVERNAME - Unshelve an instance - Restores the instance: .. code:: $ nova unshelve SERVERNAME - Remove a shelved instance - Removes the instance from the server; data and resource associations are deleted. If an instance is no longer needed, you can move the instance off the hypervisor in order to minimize resource usage: .. code:: $ nova shelve-offload SERVERNAME

subject: Remove the elevated context when get network
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-03-16 01:15:50.000000000', 'files': ['nova/network/api.py', 'nova/tests/unit/network/test_api.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/cf6b9436533238e3a43e01d260639f42e48b7590', 'message': "Remove the elevated context when get network

The os-tenant-networks API is called by non-admin user. But currently
the show and delete method can act on the network which didn't belong
to the request user. So remove the elevated context, then db call
will only return project-only networks for non-admin user, and returns
all networks for admin user.

Change-Id: I77c3a1d45c85509ca9bd204fcd0496bc4f4411da
Closes-Bug: #1432100
"}]
commit_message:
Remove the elevated context when get network

The os-tenant-networks API is called by non-admin user. But currently
the show and delete method can act on the network which didn't belong
to the request user. So remove the elevated context, then db call
will only return project-only networks for non-admin user, and returns
all networks for admin user.

Change-Id: I77c3a1d45c85509ca9bd204fcd0496bc4f4411da
Closes-Bug: #1432100

commit_message:
Handle RESIZE_PREP status when nova compute do init_instance

Handle instances in RESIZE_PREP status during service start
Instances may end up in RESIZE_PREP, when nova service starts,
we detect this state and revert it to normal status.

Change-Id: I65fc099ef6803fecc15095e208ee280550c45d25
Closes-Bug: 1389127
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/27/132827/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if (instance.vm_state != vm_states.ERROR and instance.task_state in [task_states.RESIZE_PREP]): LOG.debug("Instance in transitional state %s at start-up " "clearing task state", instance['task_state'], instance=instance) # need to revert quotas old_flavor = flavors.extract_flavor(instance) new_flavor = flavors.extract_flavor(instance, 'new_') deltas = {} if old_flavor and new_flavor: deltas['cores'] = new_flavor['vcpus'] - old_flavor['vcpus'] deltas['ram'] = new_flavor['memory_mb'] \ - old_flavor['memory_mb'] quotas = objects.Quotas() try: project_id, user_id = \ quotas_obj.ids_from_instance(context, instance) quotas.reserve(context, project_id=project_id, user_id=user_id, **deltas) except Exception: msg = _LE('Can not revert quotas') LOG.exception(msg, instance=instance) instance.task_state = None instance.save()

brances in stackforge/networking-arista project

commit_message:
Move barbican client experimental job to voting gate job

Barbican team is happy with the state of the experimental devstack
gate job in the python-barbicanclient. We would like to move it
to the gate and check pipelines. Also removes the non-voting status.

Change-Id: Id77ba4651b60268cb0b8e29d0369cfe9b53d3ff2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/34/165534/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: - name: gate-python-barbicanclient-devstack-dsvm voting: false experimental:

This introduces the first object for the cellsv2 api database.  Rather
than creating a new db api the database operations are embedded within
the object.  This keeps the logic near where it's being used.

This does make an assumption about using sqlalchemy for now.  In order
to allow for substituting the database driver we will probably want to
setup a subclassing system for objects to swap that part out.  This
would allow for finer control than we currently have.

than creating a new db api the database operations are embedded within
the object.  This keeps the logic near where it's being used.

This does make an assumption about using sqlalchemy for now.  In order
to allow for substituting the database driver we will probably want to
setup a subclassing system for objects to swap that part out.  This
would allow for finer control than we currently have.

NOTE: Testing has shown that the base.NovaPersistentObject mixin needs
to be split so that deleted/deleted_at aren't included as they are not
included in the new db tables we're adding objects for.  Alternately we
could forgo the inheritance from that class and just bring the necessary
fields/methods into this object class, though I would prefer not to do
that.

commit_message:
Add CellMapping object

This introduces the first object for the cellsv2 api database.  Rather
than creating a new db api the database operations are embedded within
the object.  This keeps the logic near where it's being used.

This does make an assumption about using sqlalchemy for now.  In order
to allow for substituting the database driver we will probably want to
setup a subclassing system for objects to swap that part out.  This
would allow for finer control than we currently have.

Change-Id: Ie4828ef02e23047c4ec88e269e3a9b21b113b9e5
Partially-Implements: bp cells-v2-mapping

added_lines: # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from oslo_db.sqlalchemy import utils as sqlalchemyutils from nova.db.sqlalchemy import api as db_api from nova.db.sqlalchemy import api_models from nova import exception from nova.objects import base from nova.objects import fields class ComputeNode(base.NovaPersistentObject, base.NovaObject): # Version 1.0: Initial version VERSION = '1.0' fields = { 'uuid': fields.UUIDField(), 'name': fields.StringField(nullable=True), 'transport_url': fields.StringField(), 'database_connection': fields.StringField(), } @staticmethod def _from_db_object(context, cell_mapping, db_cell_mapping): for key in cell_mapping.fields: setattr(cell_mapping, key, db_cell_mapping[key]) cell_mapping.obj_reset_changes() cell_mapping._context = context return cell_mapping @base.remotable_classmethod def get_by_uuid(cls, context, cell_uuid): session = db_api.get_api_session() db_mapping = sqlalchemyutils.model_query(api_models.CellMapping, session).filter_by(uuid=cell_uuid).first() if not db_mapping: raise exception.CellMappingNotFound(uuid=cell_uuid) return cls._from_db_object(context, cls(), db_mapping) @base.remotable def create(self, context): db_mapping = api_models.CellMapping() db_mapping.update(self.obj_get_changes()) db_mapping.save() self._from_db_object(context, self, db_mapping) @base.remotable def destroy(self, context): session = db_api.get_api_session() with session.begin(): result = session.query(api_models.CellMapping).filter_by( uuid=self.uuid).delete() if not result: raise exception.CellMappingNotFound(uuid=self.uuid)

commit_message:
Add InstanceMapping object

This adds the InstanceMapping object for interacting with the
instance_mapping table.

Rather than creating a new db api the database operations are embedded
within the object.  This keeps the logic near where it's being used.
This does make an assumption about using sqlalchemy for now.  In order
to allow for substituting the database driver we will probably want to
setup a subclassing system for objects to swap that part out.  This
would allow for finer control than we currently have.

Change-Id: Ide9cc7a255b886647fd424c2030beff0335e2cd3
bp: cells-v2-mapping

added_lines: # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from nova.db.sqlalchemy import api as db_api from nova.db.sqlalchemy import api_models from nova import exception from nova import objects from nova.objects import base from nova.objects import fields class InstanceMapping(base.NovaPersistentObject, base.NovaObject): # Version 1.0: Initial version VERSION = '1.0' fields = { 'instance_uuid': fields.UUIDField(), 'cell_uuid': fields.UUIDField(), 'project_id': fields.StringField(), } @staticmethod def _from_db_object(context, instance_mapping, db_instance_mapping): for key in instance_mapping.fields: setattr(instance_mapping, key, db_instance_mapping[key]) instance_mapping.obj_reset_changes() instance_mapping._context = context return instance_mapping @base.remotable_classmethod def get_by_instance_uuid(cls, context, uuid): session = db_api.get_api_session() with session.begin(): db_mapping = session.query( api_models.InstanceMapping).filter_by( instance_uuid=uuid).first() if not db_mapping: raise exception.InstanceMappingNotFound(instance_uuid=uuid) return cls._from_db_object(context, cls(), db_mapping) @base.remotable def create(self, context): db_mapping = api_models.InstanceMapping() db_mapping.update(self.obj_get_changes()) db_mapping.save() self._from_db_object(context, self, db_mapping) @base.remotable def save(self, context): changes = self.obj_what_changed() session = db_api.get_api_session() with session.begin(): db_mapping = session.query( api_models.InstanceMapping).filter_by( instance_uuid=self.instance_uuid).first() if not db_mapping: raise exception.InstanceMappingNotFound( instance_uuid=self.instance_uuid) db_mapping.update(changes) session.add(db_mapping) self._from_db_object(context, self, db_mapping) self.obj_reset_changes() @base.remotable def destroy(self, context): session = db_api.get_api_session() with session.begin(): result = session.query(api_models.InstanceMapping).filter_by( instance_uuid=self.instance_uuid).delete() if not result: raise exception.InstanceMappingNotFound( instance_uuid=self.instance_uuid) class InstanceMappingList(base.ObjectListBase, base.NovaObject): # Version 1.0: Initial version VERSION = '1.0' fields = { 'objects': fields.ListOfObjectsField('InstanceMapping'), } child_versions = { '1.0': '1.0', } @base.remotable_classmethod def get_by_project_id(cls, context, project_id): session = db_api.get_api_session() with session.begin(): db_mappings = session.query(api_models.InstanceMapping).filter_by( project_id=project_id).all() return base.obj_make_list(context, cls(), objects.InstanceMapping, db_mappings)

commit_message:
Add data sync tables to neutron db

Adds midonet_data_state, midonet_versions, and
removes midonet_task_state from the midonet database.

Partially-Implements: kilo/data_sync
Change-Id: Ie1332cc9ee301bf38f859fd0f9408de78c5cb53a
Signed-off-by: Joe Mills <joe@midokura.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/networking-midonet refs/changes/79/164079/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from midonet.neutron.db import task_db op.create_table(task_db.DATA_STATE_TABLE, sa.Column('active_version', sa.Integer(), nullable=False), sa.Column('readonly', sa.Boolean(), nullable=False), op.execute("INSERT INTO %s (id, last_processed_id, updated_at, " "active_version, readonly) VALUES" " (1, NULL, '%s', 1, false)" % (task_db.DATA_STATE_TABLE, datetime.datetime.utcnow())) op.drop_table(task_db.DATA_STATE_TABLE)
deleted_lines: TASK_STATE_TABLE = 'midonet_task_state' op.create_table(TASK_STATE_TABLE, op.execute("INSERT INTO %s (id, last_processed_id, updated_at) VALUES" " (1, NULL, '%s')" % (TASK_STATE_TABLE, datetime.datetime.utcnow())) op.drop_table(TASK_STATE_TABLE)

commit_message:
Updates k8s DIB element

DIB element was updated to match latest k8s implementation:
1. Added confd
2. init.d scripts and k8s configs were moved to k8s implementation

Change-Id: I2433561122ae3b4ca99e0c732b6e4bd3f863e167
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/murano refs/changes/71/164871/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Install Go wget -O confd https://github.com/kelseyhightower/confd/releases/download/v0.7.1/confd-0.7.1-linux-amd64 mv confd /usr/local/bin/confd chmod +x /usr/local/bin/confd mkdir -p /etc/confd/{conf.d,templates}
deleted_lines: # Install Go# Obtain init scripts git clone https://github.com/GoogleCloudPlatform/kubernetes.git kubernetes-git pushd ${SVC_ROOT}/kubernetes-git/cluster/ubuntu-cluster for file in etcd flanneld kube-apiserver kube-controller-manager kube-proxy kube-scheduler kubelet; do echo -e "start on runlevel [235]\r\nstop on runlevel [016]" >> ${SVC_ROOT}/kubernetes-git/cluster/ubuntu-cluster/init_conf/$file.conf; done cp -R default_scripts/* /etc/default/ cp -R init_conf/* /etc/init/ cp -R initd_scripts/* /etc/init.d/ popd cp -R ${SVC_ROOT}/kubernetes-git/cluster/ubuntu-cluster/* ${SVC_ROOT}/ sed -i 's/"$etcdVersion" != "2.0.0"/"${etcdVersion%.*}" != "2.0"/g' ${SVC_ROOT}/configure.sh rm -rf ${SVC_ROOT}/kubernetes-gitupdate-rc.d etcd start 70 3 4 5 . stop 20 0 1 6 . update-rc.d flanneld start 70 3 4 5 . stop 20 0 1 6 . update-rc.d kube-apiserver start 70 3 4 5 . stop 20 0 1 6 . update-rc.d kube-controller-manager start 70 3 4 5 . stop 20 0 1 6 . update-rc.d kube-proxy start 70 3 4 5 . stop 20 0 1 6 . update-rc.d kube-scheduler start 70 3 4 5 . stop 20 0 1 6 . update-rc.d kubelet start 70 3 4 5 . stop 20 0 1 6 . update-rc.d etcd disable update-rc.d flanneld disable update-rc.d kube-apiserver disable update-rc.d kube-controller-manager disable update-rc.d kube-proxy disable update-rc.d kube-scheduler disable update-rc.d kubelet disable

commit_message:
Handle DBDuplicateError exception properly when creating default sg

Previously, an exception was not caught in one of invocations
(create_network) of _ensure_default_security_group.
Move exception handling inside that method so it never fails
with such exception.

Change-Id: Ibb0597d4db187c856f9ac1d9700701e0165c3c73
Closes-Bug: #1419723

Closes-Bug: #1433794
"}]
commit_message:
Add fallback on sahara endpoint lookup

In Juno, sahara is registered as 'data_processing' in the catalog.

When endpoint for 'data-processing' is not found in  service catalog,
fallback lookup to 'data_processing' to maintain backwards compatibility
with Juno.

Change-Id: I2c1e6342f21080d7209c584c91379b4d22c517a2
Closes-Bug: #1433794
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/36/165636/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from horizon import exceptions# Sahara service_type registered in Juno SAHARA_SERVICE_FALLBACK = 'data_processing' try: service_type = SAHARA_SERVICE sahara_url = base.url_for(request, service_type) except exceptions.ServiceCatalogException: # if no endpoint found, fallback to the old service_type service_type = SAHARA_SERVICE_FALLBACK sahara_url = base.url_for(request, service_type) sahara_url=sahara_url, service_type=service_type,
deleted_lines: sahara_url=base.url_for(request, SAHARA_SERVICE), service_type=SAHARA_SERVICE,

commit_message:
Update sample httpd config file

The sample httpd config file was not using best practices for
apache configuration. The file is now a copy of the file that
devstack uses for keystone apache config
(files/apache-keystone.template), with the replacement strings
updated to the keystone defaults.

Also, the "Firewall" section is removed from the httpd config
docs because the sample config file isn't using port 443.

Change-Id: I1d10925b33ec7e70793e61db1cb99186f112ef3e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/10/164510/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Update this file to match your system configuration (for example, some distributions put httpd logs in the ``apache2`` directory and some in the ``httpd`` directory; also, enable TLS).
deleted_lines: Firewall -------- Add the following rule to IPTables in order to ensure the SSL traffic can pass your firewall:: -A INPUT -m state --state NEW -m tcp -p tcp --dport 443 -j ACCEPT it goes right before:: -A INPUT -j REJECT --reject-with icmp-host-prohibited

commit_message:
Raise exception for invalid mock assert calls

Several test cases were using the wrong mock assert methods.
The following patch corrects these calls and adds a method in
test.py (sourced from nova/test.py) to make sure they are
properly caught in the future.

Closes-Bug: #1429669
Change-Id: Ic6e5bca0c3ddbfb402e412b51e882859cb49108c

commit_message:
Added a new test case for cluster_add_nodes

Nodes that are already owned by a cluster cannot be added to another
cluster directly.

Change-Id: I2b13f32d647909c4fa4b12056ff1dd25b174842d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/senlin refs/changes/01/165401/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if inputs is None: inputs = {} def test_cluster_add_nodes_cluster_not_found(self): @mock.patch.object(dispatcher, 'notify') def test_cluster_add_nodes_node_already_owned(self, notify): c1 = self.eng.cluster_create(self.ctx, 'c-1', 0, self.profile['id']) cid1 = c1['id'] c2 = self.eng.cluster_create(self.ctx, 'c-2', 0, self.profile['id']) cid2 = c2['id'] nodes1 = self._prepare_nodes(self.ctx, count=1, cluster_id=cid1) nodes2 = self._prepare_nodes(self.ctx, count=1, cluster_id=cid2) ex = self.assertRaises(rpc.ExpectedException, self.eng.cluster_add_nodes, self.ctx, cid1, nodes1) # adding from the same cluster is not allowed self.assertEqual(exception.SenlinBadRequest, ex.exc_info[0]) msg = _("Nodes %s owned by other cluster, need to delete them from " "those clusters first.") % nodes1 self.assertEqual(_("The request is malformed: %(msg)s") % {'msg': msg}, six.text_type(ex.exc_info[1])) ex = self.assertRaises(rpc.ExpectedException, self.eng.cluster_add_nodes, self.ctx, cid1, nodes2) # adding from a different cluster is not allowed either self.assertEqual(exception.SenlinBadRequest, ex.exc_info[0]) msg = _("Nodes %s owned by other cluster, need to delete them from " "those clusters first.") % nodes2 self.assertEqual(_("The request is malformed: %(msg)s") % {'msg': msg}, six.text_type(ex.exc_info[1]))
deleted_lines: def test_cluster_add_nodes_cluster_not_found(self, notify):

commit_message:
Add support for logical names

Add client support for node logical names.

- update help strings to indicate places where Names can be used instead
  of UUIDs
- add new "-n" / "--name" parameter to "ironic node-create"
- add Name field to output of both "node-list" and "node-show"

Change-Id: Id16255e9611e95bd37a225ff475268f609726e37
Implements: blueprint logical-names

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-03-18 01:05:35.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/taskflow/commit/0879c56c4a6a0de3bf6750c7a26cfee2053cefbf', 'message': "Always return scope walker instances from `fetch_scopes_for`

Instead of returning tuples with fully expanded scopes return walker

commit_message:
Always return scope walker instances from `fetch_scopes_for`

Instead of returning tuples with fully expanded scopes return walker
instances that internally know how to avoid recomputing the visible
scopes (they do this by caching each visibility level and looking in
the local cache before computing the scope and storing it in the cache).

This makes the usage more uniform and avoids returning different items
depending on what is found; making the code easier to follow and
understand.

Also makes the scope walker call to '_extract_atoms' to go via a static
method so that if it is ever desired to alter what '_extract_atoms' does
it can be more easily done (using standard inheritance).

Change-Id: I5916838163e6be843429fe7b89a0b5622e9c2f36
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/taskflow refs/changes/62/165262/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self._visibility_cache = {} self._predecessors = None #: Function that extracts the *associated* atoms of a given tree node. _extract_atoms = staticmethod(_extract_atoms) if self._predecessors is None: pred_iter = self._graph.bfs_predecessors_iter(self._atom) self._predecessors = frozenset(pred_iter) predecessors = set(self._predecessors) try: visible, removals = self._visibility_cache[parent] predecessors = predecessors - removals except KeyError: visible = [] removals = set() for a in self._extract_atoms(parent, idx=last_idx): if a in predecessors: predecessors.remove(a) removals.add(a) if not self._names_only: visible.append(a) else: visible.append(a.name) self._visibility_cache[parent] = (visible, frozenset(removals)) if LOG.isEnabledFor(logging.BLATHER): if not self._names_only: visible_names = [a.name for a in visible] else: visible_names = visible LOG.blather("Scope visible to '%s' (limited by parent '%s'" " index < %s) is: %s", self._atom, parent.item.name, last_idx, visible_names)
deleted_lines: predecessors = set(self._graph.bfs_predecessors_iter(self._atom)) visible = [] for a in _extract_atoms(parent, idx=last_idx): if a in predecessors: predecessors.remove(a) if not self._names_only: visible.append(a) else: visible.append(a.name) if LOG.isEnabledFor(logging.BLATHER): if not self._names_only: visible_names = [a.name for a in visible] else: visible_names = visible LOG.blather("Scope visible to '%s' (limited by parent '%s'" " index < %s) is: %s", self._atom, parent.item.name, last_idx, visible_names)

commit_message:
Give the GC a break

Instead of retaining cycles which the GC will have
a harder time breaking, give it a break and use the
knowledge that the associated objects will always exist
while the runtime object does to just use a weakref
proxy so that the GC will have a easier time breaking
this cycle.

Change-Id: I6241b2f33354fa58565835a5f08e5766aa601704
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/taskflow refs/changes/48/165248/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import weakref self._runtime = weakref.proxy(runtime)
deleted_lines: self._runtime = runtime

commit_message:
Allow rc resource management by "name".

This patch supports rc API calling with name
along with the id also.

Eg.
    magnum rc-delete rc1
This will delete a rc with name rc1.

This patch supports named based resource management
for rc resource and below is the list of APIs:
    GET /v1/rcs/<name/id>
    DELETE /v1/rcs/<name/id>

Change-Id: I693da09d3d03e8498013580e88dcd40a98aa13d5
Partially-Implements: blueprint name-based-resource-management

commit_message:
Removing assertItemsEqual workaround, fixed upstream

Testtools switched to using unittest2 universally, which resolved the
inconsistencies with the assertItemsEqual function's availability. This
workaround code is no longer necessary.

Change-Id: Ic426e9fca7e475b9a42f14fff89eecaafb7937ba
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-barbicanclient refs/changes/03/165303/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: # TODO: The compatibility of unittest between versions is horrible # Reported as https://bugs.launchpad.net/testtools/+bug/1373139 if hasattr(testtools.TestCase, 'assertItemsEqual'): # If this function is available, do nothing (PY27) pass elif hasattr(testtools.TestCase, 'assertCountEqual'): # If this function is available, alias it (PY32+) assertItemsEqual = testtools.TestCase.assertCountEqual else: # If neither is available, make our own version (PY26, PY30-31) def assertItemsEqual(self, expected_seq, actual_seq, msg=None): first_seq, second_seq = list(expected_seq), list(actual_seq) differences = [] for item in first_seq: if item not in second_seq: differences.append(item) for item in second_seq: if item not in first_seq: differences.append(item) if differences: if not msg: msg = "Items differ: {0}".format(differences) self.fail(msg) if len(first_seq) != len(second_seq): if not msg: msg = "Size of collection differs: {0} != {1}".format( len(first_seq), len(second_seq) ) self.fail(msg)

commit_message:
Update Apache httpd config docs for token persistence

The Apache httpd config docs referred to the "token" driver, but
this is now known as the "token persistence" driver. Also, not
all token formats require token persistence now.

Change-Id: I42f0a227a9a665bc68dbc31d9a3ef64dc484ce05
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/08/164508/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Make sure that when using a token format that requires persistence, you use a token persistence driver that can be shared between processes. The SQL and memcached token persistence drivers provided with keystone can be shared between processes. .. WARNING:: The KVS (``keystone.token.persistence.backends.kvs.Token``) token persistence driver cannot be shared between processes so must not be used when running keystone under httpd (the tokens will not be shared between the processes of the server and validation will fail). For SQL, in ``/etc/keystone/keystone.conf`` set:: driver = keystone.token.persistence.backends.sql.Token For memcached, in ``/etc/keystone/keystone.conf`` set:: driver = keystone.token.persistence.backends.memcache.Token All servers that are storing tokens need a shared backend. This means that either all servers use the same database server or use a common memcached pool.
deleted_lines: Make sure you use either the ``SQL`` or the ``memcached`` driver for ``tokens``, otherwise the tokens will not be shared between the processes of the Apache HTTPD server. For ``SQL,`` in ``/etc/keystone/keystone.conf`` make sure you have set:: driver = keystone.token.backends.sql.Token For ``memcache,`` in ``/etc/keystone/keystone.conf`` make sure you have set:: driver = keystone.token.backends.memcache.Token In both cases, all servers that are storing tokens need a shared backend. This means either that both point to the same database server, or both point to a common memcached instance.

commit_message:
Fix minor decomp progress chart issues

Fix broken link, add missing header, and remove new contributions
from the list. This table should just capture the progress status
of existing plugins and drivers at the time the decomp was conceived.

Change-Id: Iea28443547905d979d1866b588fa91cb6d52ecc7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/67/165267/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: The chart below captures the progress of the core-vendor-decomposition effort for existing plugins and drivers at the time the decomp effort started. New drivers and plugins are not required to be listed here. This chart is short lived: once the effort is complete, this chart no longer needs to exist and will be removed. The following aspects are captured: effort is not considered justified. Assessment may change in the future.| freescale-nscs | ml2,fw | no | no | [D] | |

commit_message:
Brocade Driver for lbaas v2 data model

Change-Id: I38721a91d8c365dfadf09535c50463fa634ef7e4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-lbaas refs/changes/74/147074/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # vim: tabstop=4 shiftwidth=4 softtabstop=4 # # Copyright 2014 Brocade Communications Systems, Inc. All rights reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. # # Pattabi Ayyasami (pattabi), Brocade Communications Systems,Inc. # import brocade_adx_device_driver as device_driver from neutron.common import log from neutron_lbaas.services.loadbalancer.drivers import driver_base class BrocadeLoadBalancerDriver(driver_base.LoadBalancerBaseDriver): def __init__(self, plugin): super(BrocadeLoadBalancerDriver, self).__init__(plugin) self.plugin = plugin self.load_balancer = BrocadeLoadBalancerManager(self) self.listener = BrocadeListenerManager(self) self.pool = BrocadePoolManager(self) self.member = BrocadeMemberManager(self) self.health_monitor = BrocadeHealthMonitorManager(self) self.device_driver = device_driver.BrocadeAdxDeviceDriver(plugin) class BrocadeLoadBalancerManager(driver_base.BaseLoadBalancerManager): @log.log def create(self, context, obj): self.driver.device_driver.create_loadbalancer(obj) self.driver.activate_cascade(context, obj) @log.log def update(self, context, old_obj, obj): self.driver.device_driver.update_loadbalancer(obj, old_obj) self.driver.activate_cascade(context, obj) @log.log def delete(self, context, obj): self.driver.device_driver.delete_loadbalancer(obj) self.db_delete(context, obj.id) @log.log def refresh(self, context, lb_obj, force=False): # This is intended to trigger the backend to check and repair # the state of this load balancer and all of its dependent objects self.driver.device_driver.refresh(lb_obj, force) @log.log def stats(self, context, lb_obj): return self.driver.device_driver.stats(lb_obj) class BrocadeListenerManager(driver_base.BaseListenerManager): @log.log def create(self, context, obj): self.driver.device_driver.create_listener(obj) self.driver.activate_cascade(context, obj) @log.log def update(self, context, old_obj, obj): self.driver.device_driver.update_listener(obj, old_obj) if obj.attached_to_loadbalancer(): # Always activate listener and its children if attached to # loadbalancer self.driver.activate_cascade(context, obj) elif old_obj.attached_to_loadbalancer(): # If listener has just been detached from loadbalancer # defer listener and its children self.defer_cascade(context, obj) @log.log def delete(self, context, obj): self.driver.device_driver.delete_listener(obj) if obj.default_pool: self.driver.pool.defer_cascade(context, obj.default_pool) self.db_delete(context, obj.id) class BrocadePoolManager(driver_base.BasePoolManager): @log.log def create(self, context, obj): pass @log.log def update(self, context, old_obj, obj): self.driver.device_driver.update_pool(obj, old_obj) self.driver.activate_cascade(context, obj) if not obj.healthmonitor and old_obj.healthmonitor: self.driver.health_monitor.defer(context, old_obj.healthmonitor.id) @log.log def delete(self, context, obj): self.driver.device_driver.delete_pool(obj) if obj.healthmonitor: self.driver.health_monitor.defer(context, obj.healthmonitor.id) self.db_delete(context, obj.id) class BrocadeMemberManager(driver_base.BaseMemberManager): @log.log def create(self, context, obj): self.driver.device_driver.create_member(obj) self.driver.activate_cascade(context, obj) @log.log def update(self, context, old_obj, obj): self.driver.device_driver.update_member(obj, old_obj) self.driver.activate_cascade(context, obj) @log.log def delete(self, context, obj): self.driver.device_driver.delete_member(obj) self.db_delete(context, obj.id) class BrocadeHealthMonitorManager(driver_base.BaseHealthMonitorManager): @log.log def create(self, context, obj): pass @log.log def update(self, context, old_obj, obj): self.driver.device_driver.update_healthmonitor(obj, old_obj) self.driver.activate_cascade(context, obj) @log.log def delete(self, context, obj): self.driver.device_driver.delete_healthmonitor(obj) self.db_delete(context, obj.id)

Fix intermittent failure in test_vmware_store

The test test_delete_non_existing was failing intermittently due
to a missing mock.

commit_message:
Fixes sni_containers access issues

Updates the data model to include SNI in from_dict to fix access issues in the driver

Change-Id: I52e3ad262d3b70eace95255f043abbc12b4612ca
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-lbaas refs/changes/33/165633/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @classmethod def from_dict(cls, model_dict): return SNI(**model_dict) sni_containers = model_dict.pop('sni_containers', []) model_dict['sni_containers'] = [SNI.from_dict(sni) for sni in sni_containers]

Functional tests of ipsec strongswan vpnaas driver

This is functional test patch for strongswan driver commit [1].

[1], https://review.openstack.org/#/c/144391/

Closes-Bug: 1433223

added_lines: # Copyright (c) 2015 Canonical, Inc. # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import re from neutron.agent.common import config from neutron.agent.linux import utils from neutron.tests.functional.agent.linux import base WRAPPER_SCRIPT = 'neutron-vpn-netns-wrapper' STATUS_PATTERN = re.compile('Command:.*ip.*addr.*show.*Exit code: 0') class TestNetnsWrapper(base.BaseLinuxTestCase): def setUp(self): super(TestNetnsWrapper, self).setUp() self.check_sudo_enabled() config.setup_logging() self.fake_ns = 'func-8f1b728c-6eca-4042-9b6b-6ef66ab9352a' self.mount_paths = ('--mount_paths=/etc:/var/lib/neutron' '/vpnaas/%(ns)s/etc,/var/run:/var/lib' '/neutron/vpnaas/%(ns)s/var/run') self.fake_pth = self.mount_paths % {'ns': self.fake_ns, 'ns': self.fake_ns} def test_netns_wrap_success(self): client_ns = self._create_namespace() ns = client_ns.namespace pth = self.mount_paths % {'ns': ns, 'ns': ns} cmd = WRAPPER_SCRIPT, pth, '--cmd=ip,addr,show' output = client_ns.netns.execute(cmd) self.assertTrue(STATUS_PATTERN.search(output)) def test_netns_wrap_fail_without_netns(self): cmd = [WRAPPER_SCRIPT, self.fake_pth, '--cmd=ip,addr,show'] self.assertRaises(RuntimeError, utils.execute, cmd=cmd, run_as_root=True) def test_netns_wrap_no_command_provided(self): cmd = [WRAPPER_SCRIPT, self.fake_pth, '--cmd='] self.assertRaises(RuntimeError, utils.execute, cmd=cmd, run_as_root=True) def test_netns_wrap_no_mounted_path_provided(self): cmd = [WRAPPER_SCRIPT, '--mount_paths=', '--cmd=ip,addr,show'] self.assertRaises(RuntimeError, utils.execute, cmd=cmd, run_as_root=True) def test_netns_wrap_unauthorized_command(self): cmd = [WRAPPER_SCRIPT, self.fake_pth, '--cmd=nofiltercommand'] self.assertRaises(RuntimeError, utils.execute, cmd=cmd, run_as_root=True)

commit_message:
Mocked utils.execute for broken tests

Few tests were failing because utils.execute
was not mocked.

Added decorator @mock.patch('cinder.utils.execute')
which will mock the utils.execute call for failing tests.

Closes-Bug: #1430525
Change-Id: Ib54b83b1ad6dc42b084adf48ddd53a64a9b12cf7

commit_message:
Allow baymodel resource management by "name".

This patch supports baymodel API calling with name
along with the id also.

Eg.
    magnum baymodel-delete baymodel1
This will delete a baymodel with name baymodel1.

This patch supports named based resource management
for baymodel resource and below is the list of APIs:
    GET /v1/baymodels/<name/id>
    DELETE /v1/baymodels/<name/id>

Change-Id: Iaba98c4c622d0c051cfdc4b334af9530bcade6c3
Partially-Implements: blueprint name-based-resource-management
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/magnum refs/changes/56/165356/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def get_by_name(cls, context, name): """Find a baymodel based on name and return a :class:`BayModel` object. :param name: the name of a baymodel. :param context: Security context :returns: a :class:`BayModel` object. """ db_baymodel = cls.dbapi.get_baymodel_by_name(context, name) baymodel = BayModel._from_db_object(cls(context), db_baymodel) return baymodel @base.remotable_classmethod

commit_message:
Add fallback secure erase using shred

This prevents devices from failing cleaning if they don't support ATA
security erase. Instead, the device will be erased by overwriting using
GNU shred.

Change-Id: Ie4f88b97c8c34efe2397538662622abd0b963aea

subject: Use reasonable timeout for rpc service_update()
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-02-09 16:26:13.000000000', 'files': ['nova/service.py', 'nova/conductor/rpcapi.py', 'nova/tests/conductor/test_conductor.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/7a30e354fe34510ce38b5fd8c79d6312b75cd367', 'message': 'Use reasonable timeout for rpc service_update()

nova.servicegroup.drivers.db.DbDriver._report_state() is called every
service.report_interval seconds from a timer in order to periodically
report the service state. It calls self.conductor_api.service_update().

If this ends up calling nova.conductor.rpcapi.ConductorAPI.service_update(),
it will do an RPC call() to nova-conductor.

If anything happens which causes the RPC reply to be lost or
never sent in the first place, by default the RPC code will
wait 60 seconds for a response (blocking the timer-based
calling of _report_state() in the meantime).
This is long enough to cause the status in the database to get old
enough that other services consider this service to be "down".

if rpc_reponse_timeout is smaller than report_interval then we could
use the existing RPC timeout, but wait longer won't hurt. So the patch
didn't check it and only use report_interval.

Change-Id: I88743183bce1a534812cfe6110c3fc2892058c53
Closes-Bug: #1368989
(cherry picked from commit 197bb467c0fa33700e5397c934fa10d8c16f1fbc)
'}]
commit_message:
Use reasonable timeout for rpc service_update()

nova.servicegroup.drivers.db.DbDriver._report_state() is called every
service.report_interval seconds from a timer in order to periodically
report the service state. It calls self.conductor_api.service_update().

If this ends up calling nova.conductor.rpcapi.ConductorAPI.service_update(),
it will do an RPC call() to nova-conductor.

If anything happens which causes the RPC reply to be lost or
never sent in the first place, by default the RPC code will
wait 60 seconds for a response (blocking the timer-based
calling of _report_state() in the meantime).
This is long enough to cause the status in the database to get old
enough that other services consider this service to be "down".

if rpc_reponse_timeout is smaller than report_interval then we could
use the existing RPC timeout, but wait longer won't hurt. So the patch
didn't check it and only use report_interval.

Change-Id: I88743183bce1a534812cfe6110c3fc2892058c53
Closes-Bug: #1368989
(cherry picked from commit 197bb467c0fa33700e5397c934fa10d8c16f1fbc)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/07/154107/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from oslo.config import cfgCONF = cfg.CONF CONF.import_opt('report_interval', 'nova.service') @mock.patch.object(db, 'service_update') @mock.patch('oslo.messaging.RPCClient.prepare') def test_service_update_time_big(self, mock_prepare, mock_update): CONF.set_override('report_interval', 10) services = {'id': 1} self.conductor.service_update(self.context, services, {}) mock_prepare.assert_called_once_with(timeout=9) @mock.patch.object(db, 'service_update') @mock.patch('oslo.messaging.RPCClient.prepare') def test_service_update_time_small(self, mock_prepare, mock_update): CONF.set_override('report_interval', 3) services = {'id': 1} self.conductor.service_update(self.context, services, {}) mock_prepare.assert_called_once_with(timeout=3) @mock.patch.object(db, 'service_update') @mock.patch('oslo.messaging.RPCClient.prepare') def test_service_update_no_time(self, mock_prepare, mock_update): CONF.set_override('report_interval', None) services = {'id': 1} self.conductor.service_update(self.context, services, {}) mock_prepare.assert_called_once_with()
